prakshisaha: Firstly, I cannot even adequately put in words how @regajha makes the internet a beautiful place to be on. It's relatable, funny, real and inspiring. Secondly, this post. I always have two extreme phases. Either in my boxers, hair tied in a top knot, my acne and dark circles popping out, looking like a dead mess. Other is this extremely well dressed, make up and hair on point, bag, shoes, belt coordinated so called perfect self. People often call the second one fake and made up. I have been makeup shamed so many times. But nothing gives me that crazy confidence than a loud mouth. So, I have never been able to explain any one that I don't have to choose either of my self as a real one. Both are equally me. Your posts sometimes makes me believe it is okay to just be exactly the way I am !

jovaferreyra: Interesting thought, the last one. We’re used to using words like “anxiety” and phrases like “my brain is being unkind to me.” But I wonder if the acknowledgement of or various selves can offer new forms of expression in order for us to understand situations (and our whole selves) better.  For instance, we can say that sometimes our “higher selves” get frustrated with the basic-ass shit that our “normal selves” wind up doing over and over again. Or the way our “shadow self” takes control and makes choices out of fear, making us smaller and more constricted—pissing off the higher self and creating a tug of war within us that make us fidgety, unsure, doubtful and... anxious. Know what I mean jelly-bean? Accepting our inner team of selves and making space for all of them to work together and get along is crucial then. And if one self doesn’t play nice with the rest and is just creating chaos, can we slowly let them go? Tell them that they’re not in compliance with company culture and give them a two weeks notice?
confondue: but why couldn’t both the selves be authentic in themselves? I digress, but where’s the suit from😍
